newsitem.title: USA: US-Canada timber quota working, supporters say.
newsitem.headline: US-Canada timber quota working, supporters say.

text.p: The U.S.-Canada timber quota pact has encouraged U.S. production and has not driven up lumber prices or dried up supplies, supporters said Thursday.
In a statement, the Coalition for Fair Lumber Imports called the year-old pact "a modest means of addressing heavily subsidized Canadian imports."

The coalition presented its side of the argument a couple of hours before Representative Jack Quinn, New York Republican, was scheduled to unveil a bill at 1300 EDT to reverse the quota. Groups representing home builders, lumber dealers and retailers were to take part ln the news conference.

Under the pact reached in April 1996, up to 14.7 billion board feet of Canadian lumber can enter the United States duty-free each year. Tariffs of $50 and $100 per 1,000 board feet were liable on shipments above that level.
The coalition said U.S. timber production was up nine percent since the agreement was signed. Price volatility has declined and prices have fallen since the November 1996 peak.
Some 17.8 billion board feet of Canadian lumber were imported in 1996, the coaltion said, up 800 million from 1995.
"Plenty of lumber is available," it said.
